metadata.case_name: Maharajadhiraja Sir Kameshwar Singh of Darbhanga v. State of Bihar

facts.text: For assessment year 1944-45 (1351 Fasli), assessee returned Rs. 37,43,520 as agricultural income and claimed deduction of Rs. 9,42,137-3-10 1/2 including Rs. 2,82,192 paid to Tekari Raj from zarpeshgi leases dated August 15, 1931, and January 31, 1936, as capital receipt.
Agricultural Income-tax Officer (AITO) by order dated December 28, 1945, accepted contention, exempted Rs. 2,82,192 as capital income per bond terms, suggested it be treated as income to Tekari Raj.
Assessment approved by Assistant Commissioner on January 4, 1946; formal order and demand notice on January 5, 1946; assessee paid two instalments out of three.
On March 22, 1946, AITO recorded that agricultural income from Gaya Zarpeshgi lease escaped assessment for 1944-45, issued notice under s.26 fixing May 20, 1947.

Supplementary assessment order assessed Rs. 2,52,879 as income, tax Rs. 39,512-6-0; reasoned that per lease terms, assessee in possession to enjoy usufruct for fixed years on annual thika rent Rs.1,000, income derived taxable in assessee's hands.
Assessee appealed to Commissioner of Agricultural Income-tax, who reversed, holding income returned but exempt, not escaped assessment under s.26.
Province of Bihar moved Board of Revenue, which by resolution February 7, 1948, referred two questions to Patna High Court under s.25(1) without opinion.
Patna High Court by judgment February 19, 1952, answered both questions affirmatively for State; leave refused, special leave obtained from Supreme Court.

Zarpeshgi leases: Indentures between Rani and assessee; Rs.17,16,000 paid, possession for 28 years, annual rent Rs.1,000; no express loan term, no interest, no redemption right, no personal liability.
Cl.4 of lease allows lessee to deduct 12.5% collection charges after rent to lessor, appropriate remainder.

legal_issues.text: Whether AITO had jurisdiction under s.26 of Bihar Agricultural Income-tax Act, 1938 to revise own order dated January 5, 1946 holding zarpeshgi lease receipt not liable, as income returned but exempted.
Whether income from zarpeshgi lease taxable under the Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: Income returned and held exempt after consideration; no escaped assessment as it passed through assessment process; 'escaped assessment' requires eluding notice, not deliberate exemption; s.26 not applicable to returned but exempt income.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Maharaja Bikram Kishore v. Province of Assam; CIT v. Day Brothers; Madan Mohan Lal v. CIT; Chimanram Motilal v. CIT; Chatturam Horilram Ltd. v. CIT

petitioner_arguments.text: Zarpeshgi lease receipts capital repayment of loan Rs.17 lakhs to Tekari Raj; relation of debtor-creditor; cl.4 allows appropriation of usufruct after rent and charges as repayment.

respondent_arguments.text: Income escaped assessment even if returned and deliberately not taxed; 'for any reason' in s.26 wide; includes mistake/oversight; preponderance of opinion supports jurisdiction.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Anglo-Persian Oil Co. v. CIT; PC Mullick; CIT v. Raja of Parlakimedi; Chimanram Motilal v. CIT; Kamal Singh v. CIT

respondent_arguments.text: Zarpeshgi is lease for fixed term on fixed rent Rs.1,000; premium not loan; no interest, redemption, personal liability; income from land taxable as agricultural income in assessee's hands.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Bihar Agricultural Income-tax Act, 1938; Mulla's Transfer of Property Act

court_reasoning.text: S.26 wider than IT Act s.34 due to 'for any reason'; no need for fresh information; income returned but erroneously exempted escapes assessment; follows Kamal Singh v. CIT distinguishing cases like Chatturam.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Even if assessee submitted return, if ITO erroneously fails to tax part of assessable income, it escapes assessment.

court_reasoning.text: Documents are indentures of lease; no loan terms (no repayment, interest, redemption, liability); cl.4 exempts lessor from collection charges, not repayment; thika profits agricultural income taxable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Payment premium, not loan; income derived from land during lease tenure taxable in assessee's hands.

holdings.text: AITO competent under s.26 to assess omitted item even if returned and initially thought exempt.
Income from zarpeshgi leasehold properties is agricultural income taxable under Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kamal Singh v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bihar and Orissa
precedents_cited.relevance: S.34 applicable where income returned but deliberately held not liable; distinguishes change of mind issue irrelevant under s.26 'any reason'.

precedents_cited.case_name: Messrs. Chatturam Horilram Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bihar and Orissa
precedents_cited.relevance: Not case of mere non-assessment; inapplicable to facts.

precedents_cited.case_name: Maharaja Bikram Kishore v. Province of Assam
precedents_cited.relevance: Cited by petitioner; reviewed but not followed on escaped assessment.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Day Brothers
Madan Mohan Lal v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Cited by both; divergent views noted.

precedents_cited.case_name: Chimanram Motilal Gold and Silver, Bombay v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Cited by both on escaped assessment.

precedents_cited.case_name: Anglo-Persian Oil Co. (India) Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Supports jurisdiction even if deliberately not taxed.

precedents_cited.case_name: P.C. Mullick and D.O. Aich, In re
Commissioner of Income-tax v. Raja of Parlakimedi
Rajendra Nath Mukerjee v. Income-tax Commissioner
precedents_cited.relevance: Context of pending assessment; not applicable.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Kamakshya Narain Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Reversed Patna HC; led to reassessment in Kamal Singh.

statutes_cited.name: Bihar Agricultural Income-tax Act, 1938
statutes_cited.relevance: Reference under s.25(1); jurisdiction to reassess escaped income under s.26 'for any reason'; proceedings as per s.17(2).

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act (pre-1948 amendment)
statutes_cited.relevance: Substantially similar to Bihar Act s.26 but narrower; compared for interpretation.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed appeal, upheld Patna High Court answers to both questions in favour of State; AITO had jurisdiction under s.26 to reassess; zarpeshgi income taxable as agricultural income.

key_quotes.text: 'If for any reason any agricultural income chargeable to agricultural income-tax has escaped assessment...'; use of 'any reason' dispenses with conditions in IT Act s.34.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Interprets wide scope of s.26 jurisdiction.

key_quotes.text: Even if assessee submitted return, if Income-tax Officer erroneously fails to tax a part of assessable income, it is a case where said part has escaped assessment.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: There is no express term which makes the sum a loan returnable either by repayment or by enjoyment of usufruct. No interest fixed or right of redemption granted.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Determines zarpeshgi as lease premium, not loan.
